Q: How does the 25% co-payment for employer works under Section 2 – Hospital & Surgical Expenses?
A: Below is a table based on our 4 plans for you to take reference PlanBasicEnhancedPremierExclusive Annual Limit for Hospital & Surgical$60,000$60,000$80,000$80,000 Waiver of Co-payment (25%)NoYesYesYes Scenario 1: Helper incurs a $15,000 hospital bill for a necessary procedureWe will cover the total bill of $15,000 Scenario 2: Helper incurs a $30,000 hospital bill for a necessary procedureWe will cover the first $15,000 Next $15,000 Co-payment applies Employer: 25% x $15,000 = $3,750 Remaining $15,000-$3,750 =$11,250 Out of the total $30,000 bill Insurer will pay $15,000 + $11,250 = $26,250 Employer will have to pay $3,750We will cover the first $15,000 Next $15,000 Co-payment will be waived Employer = $0 Insurer = Settle the total $30,000 We will cover the first $15,000 Next $15,000 Co-payment will be waived Employer = $0 Insurer = Settle the total $30,000 Balance claimable limit for the year$60,000 – $26,250 = $33,750$60,000 – $30,000 = $30,000$80,000 – $30,000 = $50,000 Scenario 3: Helper incurs a $75,000 hospital bill for a necessary procedureWe will cover the first $15,000 (a) Next $60,000 Co-payment 25% applies $60,000 x 25% = $15,000 (b) Remaining 75% $60,000 - $15,000 =$45,000 (c) Out of the total $75,000 bill Insurer will pay (a) $15,000 (c) $45,000 (Benefit limit reached) We will pay up to annual limit $60,000 Employer will have to pay (b) $15,000 We will cover the first $15,000 (a) Next $60,000 Co-payment 25% will be waived $60,000 x 25% = $15,000 (b) Remaining 75% $60,000 - $15,000 =$45,000 (c) Out of the total $75,000 bill Insurer will pay (a) $15,000 (b) $15,000 (c) $30,000 (Benefit limit reached) We will pay up to annual limit $60,000 Employer will have to pay (c) $15,000 We will cover the first $15,000 (a) Next $60,000 Co-payment 25% will be waived $60,000 x 25% = $15,000 (b) Remaining 75% $60,000 - $15,000 =$45,000 (c) Out of the total $75,000 bill Insurer will pay (a) $15,000 (b) $15,000 (c) $45,000 We will pay the total bill $75,000 Employer will have to pay (c) $0 Balance claimable limit for the year$60,000 – $60,000 = $0$60,000 – $60,000 = $0$80,000 – $75,000 = $5,000
questions: How does the 25% co-payment for the employer apply under Section 2 – Hospital & Surgical Expenses across different plan levels when a helper incurs hospital bills of varying amounts, and how does this affect the insurer's payment and the employer's out-of-pocket cost?

In scenarios where the hospital bill exceeds the annual limit for Hospital & Surgical Expenses, how is the co-payment calculated and applied, and what portion of the bill is the employer responsible for under plans with and without co-payment waivers?
What is the impact of the waiver of the 25% co-payment on the employer's financial responsibility and the insurer's payment when the hospital bill is exactly at or below the annual limit?

How does the annual limit for Hospital & Surgical Expenses influence the balance claimable limit after a large hospital bill is paid, and how does this differ between plans with and without co-payment waivers?

In the case of a $30,000 hospital bill, how does the co-payment mechanism work under plans that do not waive the co-payment compared to those that do, and what is the resulting payment split between insurer and employer?

When a helper incurs a hospital bill of $75,000, how are the first $15,000 and the next $60,000 portions treated differently in terms of co-payment and insurer payment under the Basic plan versus the Premier plan?
How does the co-payment waiver affect the calculation of the employer's payment when the hospital bill exceeds the annual limit, particularly in the Premier and Exclusive plans?
What are the conditions under which the employer is required to pay a co-payment, and how does this relate to the plan's coverage limits and co-payment waiver status?

How does the insurer's payment distribution change between the first $15,000 and the subsequent amounts in hospital bills exceeding $15,000, and how is this influenced by the plan's co-payment waiver?
In what way does the co-payment percentage apply only to the amount exceeding the initial $15,000 hospital bill, and how does this affect the total amount payable by the insurer and employer?

How do the different annual limits ($60,000 vs $80,000) across plans affect the remaining claimable balance after a large hospital expense, and what role does the co-payment waiver play in this calculation?
What is the employer's financial responsibility under the Basic plan when a helper's hospital bill is $75,000, and how does this compare to the responsibility under the Enhanced plan?
How does the insurer handle hospital bills that reach or exceed the annual limit in terms of co-payment application and total payout under plans with and without co-payment waivers?
What scenarios demonstrate the insurer covering the full hospital bill without any employer co-payment, and what plan features enable this outcome?
How does the co-payment waiver affect the insurer's total payout and employer's payment when the hospital bill is between $15,000 and the annual limit?
In the event of multiple hospital bills within the same policy year, how does the co-payment and annual limit affect the balance claimable limit and subsequent claims under different plans?
How is the 25% co-payment calculated specifically on the portion of the hospital bill exceeding $15,000, and how does this calculation differ when the co-payment is waived?
What is the significance of the first $15,000 hospital bill amount in relation to co-payment and insurer payment across all plans?
How does the co-payment waiver influence the insurer's payment breakdown when the hospital bill is significantly higher than the annual limit, such as $75,000?
Under what conditions will the employer have zero co-payment liability despite large hospital bills, and how do plan features like co-payment waiver and annual limits contribute to this?
